Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.

Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for JEDDA, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, ADEN.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: PETER'S THE ORIGINAL MILK-CHOCOLATE
div.p: D. PETER INVENTOR
VEVEY SWITZERLAND
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM
div.p: The following extract is from the interesting lecture on "The White Nile and the Cotton Crop", delivered by Sir William WilloockK.C.MG FRGS, in continuation of his lecture delivered on 27th Dec. 1907, at a meeting of the Khedivial Geographical Society on Saturday. Sir William looks to the construction of a barrage at the point of junction of the Blue and White Niles at Khartoum as the most necessary engineering effort whiob onald be made to save Egypt from the disastrous effects of a low Nile, which though considerably reduced since the construction of the Assouan dam are still a menace to the country. For a sum of less than LE 8,000,000, he affirms that works sufficient for the storing of three milliards of cubic metres of water would be complisher, and the Assuan tr servoir surpasword many times. Toe pasag dealing with the raining of the Dam is as
follows:

Out of the six milliards cubic metres of water needed for Egypt, the Assouan reservoir will be in a position to supply two For the other four milliards we have only to turn to tbo terminal reach of the White Nilo with its wide channel about 1,000 kilometres long, with no slope in 500 kilometres and a slope of 1 100,000 in the remaining 500. Nature, which has, as a rule, been so niggardly in Africa bas opened ber lap to Egypt and given of ber good things with a tree hand. While Egypt needed lain in gation for 7,000 years, the muddy waters of the Blue Nile floud sopplied ber Lee's, arteri by the still more turbid waters of the Atba. Wben tw day we need to store clear water for the stater on a gigantic scale, the Wuite Vile is rewly with its reservoir-like bio to weet every neert of the country and of the Sudan.

Since giving my last lecture on the reservoir of the White Nile it has been pointed out to me that the late Sir Betijamin Paker only recommended the raising of the Assuan dam by 7 metres as a counsel of despair His opi Diuis contained in Blue Brok Egypt No. 7 of 1907, which appeared when I was ill and when no professional literatnre was allowed to enter my bands. I have just seen it. Here are his words: "If additional water is a national necer sity. I bave no hesitation in recommending that the raising and strengthening of the

ovan dam, in accordance with the designs submitted, be carried out, no alternative plan of a resonable and practical kind can, in my pinion, be deviser for storing the required quantity of water." Sir Benjamin bad dover seen the White Nile, and possibly the levels Wrre not then available.

The White Nile from Khartoum right op to Lake No is, as has been already pointed out, very nearly a lake in flood and would stay lake for ever if the Blue Nile were subjeot to perpetual finod. Hetween low summer and high flood there is a difference of 8 metres. We want a masonry works which will keep this impounded water where it is when the Blue Nile has tailen, and deliver it just when we need it, pot superabundantly in the latter balf of Ootober, November and December, and in de ficiency in April, May and June, b. t vicerere A tarrage with 30 opening like the Esna bar. rage built at the poiut of junction of the Blue and White Niles, and holding op 4 metres of Water, and & necond biber up the White Nile Dear, Gordon Tree, impounding furtber metres, would between them form a reservoir of extraordinary magnitude. The reservoir woull contain some three milliards of oubio metres of water, and would suffice fur Egypt and the Sudan for many years If this combination were not considered the best, a combinationof barrage at the junction of the Blue And White Niles with another at the Aba Zeid furd, would form a still more powertul reservoir. Then there in the Saubat mouth which is available. A combination of the three sites would bring us to the conceptions of the builders of the Pyramids and the construoton of Lake Mæris. Not only cald we store all the water veeded tor Egypt and the Sudan, but I believe we could bave such an effect on a very bigb Nile that the dangers of an inundation would materially be decreased. We are on the thres bold of as wonderful andas startling discoverins as any made by any hydraulic engineers in the world to begin with, three years would suffice to carry out the preliminary works storing three milliards of cubic, metres of water, while the onet would be under L.B. 3,000,000. The Assuan reservoir would be surpassed many times

But whatever works are carried out anywhere, the necessity of a reservoir at Assuno remains unaffected. This question was give into thor oughly, and this is the opinion we came to. I quote from my 1895 Report: "We have con cluded that it is absolutely necessary in the interest of irrigation to bave near at band, at the point where the Nile euters Egypt, a reserve of water to meet any contingencies which inight arina. There contingencies might arise from the fact that some of the more important su un mer crops are incapable of standing ten-days' drought, while the summer discharge of reservoirs bigh up the Nile would take many days to rowoh Egyps, and might sometimes be late in arriving"

London, Thursday. There is a marked improvement on the Stock Exchange Cheap money has created a renewal of public interest and there is a substantial demand for the best stocks. Prices are bigber all round. A feature of the buoyancy in CONNOIS which are quoted at 864.

div.head:
BORSE AND BANKING CO. OF EGYPT LTD.
REMOVAL OF LIQUIDATOR
div.p: This morning the British Consular Court at Alexandra ordered the removal of Mr. Alfred Nahman from his post of liquidator of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited and the deposit of the books, dooutent, monies, etc., of the Company with the registrar of the Court pending the appointment of a new liquidator under section 141 of the companies acts of 1862. Mr. Reginald Billey appeared on behalf of the applicant, British shareholder in the company. The liquidator was represented by Mr. Whitworth

div.head:
LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL AND
GENERAL ASSEMBLY
div.p: The petition against the election of Sheikh Ali Yoose to the Legislative Council hos proved successful and last night the election of the Sheikh wm declared null and void. The elections of Ibrahim Bey Ragi and Mohamed Pasba Hassan to the General Assembly were also annulled, but the election of Sheikh Demerdache to the Assembly was upheld

div.head: POST OFFICE EMBEZZLEMENT
div.p: The cashier of the Mansourah Post Office having embezzled groups of specie of the approximate value of LE 1.000 be has been immediately arrested and handed over to the Parquet which has opened judicial inquiry. The Postal Administration has, however, issued instructions to the Mansourah Post Office to the effect that the amounts in question be paid to the various addresses without delay

div.head:
SHEPHEARD'S GRAND BALL
A GREAT FUNCTION
div.p: The efforts made by the management of Shepheard's Hotel to restrict the number of invitations to their balcotillon were evidently of no avail, for the attendance even greater than last year, when if we remember rightly the numbers totalled about 1,200 persona. 80 great was the crusb in the hotel at ten o'clock on Wednesday that it ww matter of great difficulty to arrive even so farm the dressing rooms, and there women solute dead block in the partage leading to the ballroom. lo spite of the numbers however, which after all proved the enormous popularity of the function, the hell was most wonderfully successful one, and, if ones memories are trifle bary after such an orening, they retain impressions all of the pleasetest nature.

Brilliant illuminations and masses of foliage decorated the handsome ballroom with its splendid floor bordered by long rows of chairs Subdued coloured lights abone over the e deductive furnishings and through the softly falling fountain of water in the mljoining spacious wlon and in ballroom, salons, parrages, Egyptian ball and everywhere, such crowds of people were gathered that the babel of cherry voices and the music of happy laughter at times almost overpowered the strains of the orobestias

The chief interest centred naturally in the ballroom, where rows of spectators lined the walls so deeply that there was but little space left for those who wished to dance. There was but little hope of ever finding one's partners, and the programs, arranged so hastily friend drifted past friend in the crowd collected in the passages, were nseless after they once were parted. Bat a reeri minations on either side of the compact were futile, no ill-feeling was evinced, and for the most part people spent each number of the programme happily enough with those who happened to be nearest to them at the moment

The great event of the evening naturally was the cotillon placed between the fifth and sixth dance, when the ranks of spectators became so dense that those participating in it could scarcely force their way through, in spite of the ropes which were supposed to clear the space for them. A committee of ladies and gentlemen had been elected to assist in the proceeding, the leading part being vested in Mrs. Irene Harvey and her squire Dr. Brabant. These two followed by their committee and many other couples made the circuit of the room carrying the insignia of their office, brilliant orders and gay rosettes, dainty chapend on the heads of the ladies, white paper peroques and three cornered hats giving a somewhat incongraona appearance to their cavaliers. The ladies also carried long branches of enormous paper flowers, so that as they tripped up and down to gayest strains of music, the centre of the room took the effect of an ever revolving kaleidoscope. Eventually they took their positions

to leave DATTOW passage down the centre leading from end to end, and, the long curtains suddenly parted, there appeared · tiny flower decked sleigh drawn by tiny donkey and occupied by three tiny mites clad in soft white furs. In place of snow Maker, Horal favours were soon talking through the air, until the little chariot was bereft of all its decorations and disappeared again behind the curtains. After this pretty surprised the floor was taken by another little lady of tender years, Min Stella Sneath who performed a very graceful little pas seul in a space which was all too small for her pretty flutterings and gyrations. Owing to the press of the crowd it was not able to continue the remainder of the cotillon figures, and soon the buffet was thrown open, and the numbers thinned the ordinary pro Kram mewu resumed. A word of congratulations and thanks to the management in bere due for the excellence and superabundance of this aforementioned buffet, which con taided all the elements necessary for substantial supper and enough liquid refreshment to float first class dahabeah

It is impossible to mention bundrerith part of the bomber of people who were pre ment, but we have pleasure in mentioning those who were instrumental among the committee of stewards and those who assisted Mr Irene Harvey and Dr. Brabant in the Cotillon. These latter included the Misses Hersheimer, Miss Traub, Miss Liddell and the Mines Chesney, while among the gentle men were Meurs. Dickenson, Willie Taylor Bennett, Prost and Chapman

A few of those noticed in the ballroom were - Count Koziebrodski, Baronne Imbof and the Misses Imhof, H. B. Nubar Pasha Baron Rob. Heyn, Cape and Mrs. Schreiber, Mr. P de Martino Boy, Baron de Villefangue, Mr de Wagner, Lord and Lady Lain Clower, Dr. and Mrs Nolan, Mr. and Miss Hunting Howell, Mr and Miss Devereux, Capt. and Mn. G. C M. Hall, Mr. and Mr. H Reboel sod family Mr. and Mrs Roete, Mr. and Mrs. Iddinga, Mr. Camel Towegs, Mr and Mme Barois and the Missee Barois, Mme de Teher Davide, Mr and Mrs. Cattaoui, Mr. and the Misses Annealey, Col. Mr and Miss Davidson, Mr. and Mrs. Carver, Misa de Bilinski, Mr. and Mr. Tite, Mr. and Mrs. A V. Thomson, Mis Johnstone, Mn. Merkl and Miss Monde, Capt. and Mrs. Morgan, Mim James, Mn. Maclean and Miss Barnes Lawrence, Dr. Triler, Dr Beddon, Mrs. Bewley, Major and Mrs. Stevenson, Mr. and Mn Chatterton Adams, Mr. Donglas Sladen and Miss Potter, Mis R Holand, Mise Schuyler Rom, Mine Molo-worth,

div.head: PROTECTION AGAINST CHOLERA SYSTEM OP PROPHYLAXIS
div.p: A circular has been issued by the Sanitary Department of the Alexandria Municipality giving in full detail the steps which will be taken to prevent the sprearl of cholera, should it aver reach this town, and also instructing the poblic how to guard themselven, in so far as possible, from the disease, should it become epidemic. This latter point appears to us to be of the most importance to our readers, and, though it torms the conclusion of the circular, we will give it first consideration.
The foremost consideration in protecting the person against the cholers is cleanliness, and the circular instructa us to :
Wasbour hands after every visit to lieux d'aisance" and each time before eating
Eat only well-cooked tood, avoid altogether enfiltered water, oncooked milk and botter, vegetables and fruits which can be neither cooked nor peeled
Avoid all excess of food, generally, and too cold drinks
Call in the doctor imtaediately on the slightest suspicion
Wateh your servants, do not allow them to go out withont changing their clothes and washing their hands on returning do not allow the boabs to have any persons not belonging to the building with them
A special register will be kept at each othee for the entrance of complaints

div.head: SPECIAL TOWN INSPECTIONS,
div.p: Ano ber point of extreme importance is that regarding special inspection in town, which boe been decided upon as follows

The three inspectors of unbealthy establish ments will be especially charged to inspect and disinfect daily with carbonate of lime the mongue latnes, mineral water factories ice factories, and "boor" tactories" and all "vin" and "rebalas" will be removed from public places

A special inspection will be instituted for milk in the stables during transport and in the daires Vomeroon samples of milk have already been analysed in the laboratories and the adulterators prosecuted. Also, and espe cially in so far a foreigrers are concerned, inspection for auch being hardly efficacious, the Municipal chemist will pay sudden visits to the dairies with a consolar delegate to make A complete analysis on the spot. If the milk is found to be adulterated it will be thrown into the street.

A Manicipal regulation will be immediately effected satborising the closing of a number of infected wells in the town, and this work will commence in the quarters where there are many markets and sale of foods endangered by these wells.
The Coastguard cruiser "Noor el Bahr" has left Suez to patrol the Red Sen between Mersa Haleib and Ashraf Lightoure to prevent the pilgrims from crossing in shows

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY
div.p: Captain RK. Lynch-Staunton, Royal Field Artillery and Lieutenant W.H. Gitlist, R.A. M.C. bave been formally seconded for service with the Egyptian Army.
Captain and Brevet Major C & Wilson, Lancashire Fusiliers, serving with the Reyptian Army, has been transferred to the East Lanca | sbire Regiment, and remains woonded while in the Kbedive's service

Captain R. J. Rawson, Northumberland Pusiliers, who is serving with the Egyptian army, has been re-transferred to the Gloucester sbire Regiment, which was his original regiment, and from which he was specially promoted captain into the "Pighting Pith when it was raised to four line battalion vorpe. He remains with the Egyptian army.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prove Miru Rita Khan and theneral Obangan kban left for Constantinople yes terlay by the "Ismailia"
Gazi Mokhtar Pabe, who is still confined to bed with gastric catarrh, is undergoing trentrent under the hands of Dr Her and Dr Naim el Din Bey Aarit

We are glad to learn that Sir Ackland Colvin, who has been ill for a long time past, is sufficiently recovered to be fit to be removed in an ambulance from his home, The Lodge, Rarl Soham, to the residence of his son-in-law, Dr. Groom, st Sarbiton. He will probably stay at Surbiton for a time, and afterward go abroad for several months. He seemed in coellent spirita when leaving home, but very el
Lord any Lady Brownlow, who are now in residence at Belton House, Dear Gratham, are contemplating trip in the near future to Egypt, where they will remain for about two months

Captain W V. Paber, M. P. for the Audover Division, who is still suffering from the effects of the fall be had while bunting with the Pytebley Hounds, and neuritis in the back which ho set in, in coming to Beypt M soon as he is able to travel

The many friends in Egypt of Barones de Malortie will be interested to hear that she recently contributed an excellent article to "The Monthly Review," from the diaries of her husband, the late Baron de Malortie, formerly Censor of the Press to the Egyptian Government. The article is too long for reproduction in our columns, but we will be pleased to lend the copy of the Review containing it to any friend of the Baroness in Egypt desirous of pursuing this remarkably well written example of her literary ability.

Two officers who served in the Exyptian war died last week, Colonel Wellesley Gordon Robinson C.B., and Colonel E. V. Lake, C.B. Colonel Robinson, was senior commissariat officer at the base and on the lines of communication during the campaign and for his services he was promoted to deputy commissary general, mentioned in despatches, received the medal and claspa, the Third Close Osmanieh, and the Khedive'Star, Colonel Lake was present at the battle of Telel-Kebir, and received the medal and the Khedive's Star.

The meeting in connection with the British Constitution Association, to be held at Guild ford on the 31st at which Lord Cromer will preside will be addressed by Major General Sir Edmond Eller, Sir William Chance, Sir H. Seton Karr, Mr. J. St. Leo Strooy, and Sir Magnus, M.P.

Count Lettichan, Sir B. Scott, Baron and Barones de Turck, Captain and Mr. Rose, and Captain and Mrs. Deveninh were among the passengers, who left Alexandria yesterday by the North German Lloyd 8.8. Schleswig"

div.head:
OPENING OF PARLIAMENT
SPEECH FROM THE THRONE
ANNOUNCEMENT OF BILIS

div.p: House of Commons. The speech from the Throue - "The visit of the Emperor and Empress of Germany has been a source of great pleasure to me and the Queen. Their cordial reception by my people was warmly appreciated and cannot fail to confirm the friendly relations existing between the two nations My relations with the foreign powers continue to be friendly
"My Government has joined with the Governments of Praboe, Germany, and Russia in a trenty for preserving the integrity of Norway. The treaty will be published in due course

"The condition of the Christians and Mosul mans in Macedonia i unimproved Bands of different nationalities continue a campaign of violence, giving serious Case for anxiety The Powers have agreed to present to Turkey scheme for the improvement of her judiciary Great Britain has made further proposals to the Sultan and the Great Powers for dealing etfactually with the causes of disturbance I trust that the negotiation Dow proceeding between King Leopold and the Belgian Government will secure a humane administration of the Congo
"I hope that proposals for making better provision for old age will be submitted in con Dection with the year's financial arrangements
Bills to amend the licensing and education questions, and law to regulate labour in mides and the housing of the working classes, and to extend university education in Ireland are also announced.

div.head: A DISGRACE TO ALEXANDRIA
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EYGPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir, I have read in your paper of today the letter of an "Indignant Britisher" who under the heading "A Disgrace to Alexandria" writes about the standing of the sailing vessel under the very windows of the town and who rightly indignant at the utter lack of bringing help to ships which are in distress right at the mouth of the harbour in which they hope to find protection from the gale which they haul to fight

We may well ask "What is Civilization Alexandria 20 years ago win the richest harbour of the world and it is said that an enormous Pharos built partly of gold and Ivory greeted the ships making their way to this port, which owed its wealth grently to commerce based on the activity and courage of NAVIA tion What does this port after now in the ve of Civilization to those crafts which is dependent for its existence
Bills for tonnage and lighthouse dues whe are the hea viet, of among the bea viest level in all ports of the world, and not even an apparatus for throwing a rocket with a line to a boat in distress

And what is the worst of all and shume in the face of Europe if we can believe Mr. Pollatschek in his report to the Nouvelles those who with great self denial went to the rescue of the crew who were being drowned to their small boat had to fight with the count guard who wanted to obstruct this act of humanity and they were beaten by infuriated soldiers who, Mr. Polatschek wys were under the command of an officer of European Nationality However in this possible sud bow in it possible that the exhausted wilors, instead of being brought to the hospital had to pass the night in a wooden shanty on the shore! Were the authorities afraid of cholera being brought to Egypt by a crew which had been isolated on willing Vessel for weeks, or were they afraid that these drowning sailors were trying to smuggle "hasheesh! If the officers in command on the coast were not capable or authorized to judge this question, having strict orders, bow is it that in such an urgent case their chiefs were not there to decide immediately on a humane treatment of the victims of the accident! The whole town knew that a ship was in diesem What did the goal ling station dot Nothing whatever, mit ap pears, and the only intervention of the authority consisted in a trial to prevent the crew being saved. If this be true, who is responsible for such a cruel absurdity!

There is no doubt that this port is badly in need of Lifeboat and general resume orige In Europe a great deal is done by benevolent contributia and borders of life are uved every year through bonta kept by benevolent fanda, but it is probably very difficult to arrive at a solution of the question in this way in Egypt. Your correspondent "Humanitas" proposes that the funds saboribed to the Lord Cromer Memorial might be deployed to the purchasing and the endowing of litebont, but I think that this is a matter of consideration for the British Colony in this country alone and not the appropriate way of doing things. There is no doubt that the Egyptian Government har the urgent duty to take this matter in band. The most efficient way of providing constant fond for a rescue tag and lifeboat station would be to take a certain tax from the tonnage of crafts frequenting the barbour, but don are already heavy enough and should not be in creared Shipping pays enormous amounts yearly into the Porta and Lights Administration and there is no doubt that certain amount of the sums paid by sbipe coming to this barbour should be employed for offering safety to ships and passengers not only by breakwaters and quay but also by the necessary appliances to rescue crafts and lives which are in danger right in view of the cost

If the Government takes the initiative there is no doubt that voluntary contribution will also come forward. The porchase and endowing of litebost does not cost an enormous som and the corporation of the pilota which gains

goort deal of money through the privileges given them should be obliged the first to help ships which come here to bring them profit and should furnish the hands to mana boat. I'p to now they seem to be after their protit only without any sense of moral responsibility

The name of Lord 'roter has been men troped and there is no doubt that he still has a keen interest in the welfare of Boynt which country he has tried to TRIME into the groep of civilized nations. His support or influence would certainly be of great help in the matter under discussion, but we must not forget that bus successor with us and I think that we shall see that Sir Eldon Gorst will be one of the first to stretch out his hand to those who are in danger of lite 10 sight of the coast of the country, for which we all hope he will be second Land Cromer.
Yours truly

div.head: THE NEW PASS
div.p: T TH EDITOR THE FLYPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir. Most of us Britishers have read the celebrated letter of the Emperor Hadrian in which he depicts the Alexandrian of his day in anything but flattering terms to judge from the effonions in the Phare" and the Gazette during its tw.latinues the Imperial Roman would confirm his mrly impresion could he repeat his visit just nu The libelled Grent Prex has already visticated itself in your Columns, and now, we have an "Indignant Britisher who, although, like the **Phare, in shaointe ignorance of the frets of the case, not ashamed to crat, with sheer. At one of his countrymen the responsibility for the absence of a lifeboat service from Alexandra Had the indignant Britisber taken the trouble to enquire, he would have found that this question, which is one only of £ d . hart within the last few years been laid before HM Representative, and taken up by the Financial Adviser and the International Chamber of Shipping which latter, after repeated meetings and discussions, failed to find a solution to the question of how the necessary funds to maintain the lifeboat service were to be provided. The indignant Britisher, who would have done better an regards impressing the public with the sincerity of his philanthropic indignation by taking the course suggested by "Humanitarian" in your columns must be aware that, Great Britain, life bont services are entirely maintainer! by voluntary contributions
I am, &

div.head: PAYS LIMITROPHES.
div.p: THE EDITOR THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, Some years since ID an important article on international law, Prench writer, who presumably knew the use of his own language, said that one of the few advantages of England as compared with the countries of central Europe, was that it had to "paya
mitrophes
In your issue of the 24th inst. Me. Duke Beker tells us that as Egyptino Copy WM undoubtedly within its rights in Investing its shareholders money in Cyprus
(1) Because its statutes provide for opening dans des pays limitrophes a l'Egypta," and
2. Because the opening of busine.in Cyprus was voted in due format a general meeting of shareholders.

With regard to the first contention maintain that Cyprus divided wit is from Egypt by 300 miles of son, is not in the legal or any other sense of the word, "pays limitropbe" and that being the one no general meeting of shareholders, can legally improve on other shareholders, or on the public, the las applying to limited liability

The only legal effect which such a meeting could have, would be to make the shareholders who approved this measure, jointly liable, with the directors for the one and that liability would not in my opinion be a limit

ODO While thanking Mr. Duke Baker for his reference to my latter of the 28 inat I beg to say that it does not in any way reply to the question I raised, and I should be glad if any of your readers would do so, and such a reply would interest many people in this country besides myself

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB
div.p: SECOND WINIER MEETING

After two of the worst days we have ever experienced in Egypt we rejoiced greatly in a really fine day for the races. On the 26th the pliance of racing looked poor, but the come dried in wondertel way and the going w excellent-josta we bit soft in few places but nothing to matter the times were naturally not as fast a s a hard course
Sir Eldos aod Lady Gorst were present and the attendance was decidedly good.

The fields in some of the race dwindleri down rather, but we witnessed some very good finishes in the first race the starter pony broke loome and nosed & little diversion Nleyban ran a good noe, this is his second win this season on this coure He is evidently

good pony - Add we wish his sporting owners further lack with him. The Grand National Steeplechase was most interesting We are sorry to hear that Capt. Drake dis located his shoulder when he came down on Chamı. It was feared the pony was badly burt at first, but it was apparently only stunned, be so bsequently got up and walked off. We congratulate Major Protheroe Smith on his win on Petrone, he certainly deserves a turn of luck

Hector ran well for second place and Chater made a good deal of the running at first, but could not quite last Mr. Evane on Fares had the bad luck to lose a stirrup, and this handi capped him a good deal in the third toe. Digby rode an excellent roe and matched the victory from Piers, who at one time seemed to hold the Thor. In the fourth event, Karl Cedar was made favourite be ran well and looked like winning. Reyal Medallist, bowever, lasted better and won by 19 lengths Red Cedar is a first class wanty bred, bred in Bopt by Mr. Branch, and it in a notable feet that he can run with and bent a good many English thorough bred borser. This is an instance of what can be done in the borse breeding line in Egypt, and ought to encourage owners to take it up to a greater extent in the 5th race the start was not quite so good as usual. Speculation weut off at a great pace, but was caught by Sartik and had to be content with cond place. Abou Nadara won the last race comfortably. Digos scoring his second win for the day
The lotteries on the day before the race failed to fill. They will be held at the Turi Club on 30th at 3.80 and we hope will be better supported the time

Xisi, January 24 The old most running round the walls of Nicola has largely been planted with trees, or istised for growing barley, but the part of it knowo par excellence me "the most to the inhabitants of NICOMA was the scene of Unca activity for over a week Dunng the first two days of tourban Batam, Djereed was played every afternoon by the Zapties, large crowds of Turks and other asembling on the rain

rts to watob the contents On the third morning of Barren tbe Annual Hore and Cattle Show was held and on Friday afternoon January 17 the Cyprus Military Police held their annual sports, and 00 Saturday the 18th and 19th the Turkish Sporting Club also held their sports,

For the Zaptie Sports the weather had changed from the day before, and it was lovely, sunny, still atternoon, though with a good nip in the air. There were 12 evenita aod good number of entries for each.

An excellent tea was provided by Mr Leer mouth and Mr. Bayly H.E the High Com missioner, Lady King Harman and Miss G. King Harman were on the ground trom early in the afternoon, and H. E afterwards present ed the prizes to the successful competitors. One unfortunate occurrence marred the enjoy. ment of the afternoon. During one of the races the crowd bad encroached upon the course, and one of the horses dashed into the people. One little boy, the son of an English resident, was knocked down by it and rather badly burt, and two other children were knocked down by the crowd. The matron of the hospital at once attended to the child, who w carried to aneighbouring bouse, and the doctor was soon on the spot. At first it was feared that the injuries the child had received were very severe, but we are glad to be able to report that be tow out of danger and progreso ing favourably. The other children were only slightly hurt
Of late your the Turks have taken very really to all kinds of games, but the enta blishinent of the Turkish Sporting Glub in

mething new Their first publie entertainment was very well organized and drew large crowds to witness it, both on the Saturday and Sunday Tom was provided by the club and many of the English residents secepted their invitation and were present, though the weather of the Sunday was not very pro pitious

Thursday, being Accession Day, "the day on which His Majesty began bu happy reign." the special service provided for that day was held in the church at Nicosis. The service was fully coral, and well attended H. B. dur Charles King Harman read the lessons and short address was given by the chaplain.

January 25th being St. Paul's Day is always regarded by the Anglican Church in Cyprus La important event, being the Patronal Pestival of the Church at Nicosia This year there are to be special services, beginning with choral Evensoog on Friday 24th at 6.14 I - cluding matics and choral celebration on Saturday sud concluding with Pestal service on the Sunday

The weather has been very cold this work. On Thursday morning there was exceptigo ally beavy fall of show on the Kyrenia moun tains the southern side of the range, being qoite white almost to its base. A monfall of Auch severity on these mountains has not been known for several years past At Kyrenia itself the weather has been bitterly cold, the mountains in Anatolia present magnificent spectacle shining white across the san bat the keen winds that blow over the cause much misery to any of the poorer inhabitants of this favoured pass of the island.
Very heavy falls of snow are also reported on the Troodos range.
Mr. J. Backnill, the King's advocate, proceded last week to Port Said for the purpore of meeting his children, and is to being the back with him this mail

The te wie it the British Museum is outer

and is to be reen inside s i n the first Egyptian room, where minutes and mummy cases from the earliest perul are exhibited in the main in chrono legical opler It belongs to the time of the New Empire circa 1400 , and the body inside in thout Hekt Web, a priestess of Amen of
to the chief goud of Thebes. On the site
that city it was discovered, and it arrived in Landeny a few days ago

Sot the least remarkable thing about it is the matter in which it bas escaped injury Rince the day, some 3,300) years ago, when some loving bands reverently put the body in this gorgeous receptacle. The gold ornamentation in almost as bright as it was then, and but for * very slight cbip in the outer case at the ex treinity covering the font (and even bere the piece is preserved it is absolutely perfect.

Both in this outer cane and the cartonsago," which is composed of layers of linen pressed and glued together like pasteboard, and overed with suceo, the head and bands are gilded The bands, which bave delicate taper in fingers, are crossed over the chest in the attitnile usually seen on our old English mong mental ethigie: The beaddress is of black, with & gold and The (84 is cover with ancient Egyptian wntin which is esily deciphered by experts in the main it consista of quota tions from the Funeral Ritual or Book of the Dead, a cllection of prayers of a magien ober ster, referring to the future condition of the disembodied soul

Of this priestess Hekt Meh nothing is known In all probability, however, she belonged to a wealtby family The ancient Beyptians, it is well known, lavished money upon the preservation of their dead, under the belief that the soul returned at some time or another to the body it had formerly inhabited. If the priesters spint should revisit the spot where her remains to rest she will find berselt in

domsty Close to ber are remains of that King of the IV th dynasty who built the Third Pyramid at Gizeh, and on all hands are the tunties of high officials and priests Im tertintely beneath her in the same glass case is the mummy of Heru, an incense bearer of the Temple of the gut bensin at Thebes

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: LA Commission Municipale s'est réunie bier
4 b. p.m sous la présidence de M. Stross, doyen d'Age en l'absence de 8 E. Schiesa Pacha

Etaient présents MM Benachi, Rieti Foster, Barbazza, Rothaker, Escoffier, Kingham, Salvago, Comanos, Ralli, Abani Bey, Ayoub Bey, Mahfour Bey, Penderl, Dr. Valensin, Zer vadachi, Ehrlich, Padoa Bey, W P Chataway, administrateur, I. Sidky Bey et Wilner, secre taires
Los proces-verbaut de la Commission et de la Délégation ont été approuvés

Lecture a été doopée d'une lettre du Midis tere de l'Intérieur informant qu'il n'a pas d'ob jection, vu les circonstances toutes spéciales de la question. A ce qu'il soit doone suite au vote pris par la Commission Municipale, relatif sex gratifications de L E 500 et au don de 3400 pics de terrain l'occasion du gaine l'affaire Bismot

Lecture a été donnée également d'une lettre du Consulat de France informant que le Gou vertiement de la République decide la réu Dion d'un congres qui ne tienden & Paris en 1908 en vue d'étudier les questions relatives 'aptation des routes aux nouveax modes de locomotion et invitant la Municipalité adhérer ce congrès. L'invitation a été accep tée et à la réception du règlement de ce congres la Commission nommers un délégué et votera le crédit nécessaire
Kamel Bey Teymour a touné sa démission de conseiller municipal
Le tarif des voitures antomobiles are a cepté pour six mois

Une longue discussion s'est engagée sur l'offre d'érection d'une statue & Dante Alighieri Il s'agit, d'après la lettre du Com. Pauluoci, d'un chef d'oeuvre du fameux sculpteur Barbela, en marbre fin de Carrare de 6 mètres de hau teur. M. D. Rieti a fait ressortir que la ville était pauvre en monumenta, qa'elle abritait une forte colonie italienne laborieuse, quel vre contribuerait a l'ornementation de la ville et qu'il ne serait pas mauvais de répondre an reprocbe fait notre ville d'etre uniquement préoccupée de négoce par un peu d'idéal. La proposition n'a d'ailleurs pas rencontré d'ob jection sérieuse, sinon de la part de Abani Bey qui, sans discuter la valeur de porte, ne voit pas quel service il a rendu la ville : Abani Bey semble redouter une invasion étrangère de statues. On fini par décider que le chef d'ouvre serait place dans un paro quelconque situé dans le périmètre de la ville, plusieurs membres ont cependant proteste formellement contre son installation dans le pare de la plme Ste-Catberine
La principale question l'ordre du jour était celle des mesures prophylactiques à pren dre pour le cas d'apparition d'une épidémie de cholera

M. Recoffier revient sur la fourniture d'eau filtrée . Ramleb en exprimant l'espoir que M Salvago, membre du conseil d'administration de la Compagnie des Eaux plaiders cette cause devant ses collègues Le Dr Valensin appuie cette motion et prie la Compagnie de se montrer un peu plus charitable envers le public, il rappelle que lean constitue le prin cipal véhicule de toutes les maladies M Sal vago répond qu'il n'est pas au courant des desideratas de la Monicipalite mais que lui et ses collègues sont disposés faire tout ce qu'ils peuvent pout prévenir une épidémie en ville. Abani bey, tout en remerciant M Sal vago pour ses assurances, dit que le public est aux prises avec des employés qui sont animés de tout autres sentiments. Il voudrait que M. Salvago et ses collègues s'occupent de morti fier cette mentalité de leur personnel, qui ne prête pas foi aux coutrata de location qu'on lui présente En outre, la Compagnie devrait donner plus de publicité & son tarif la masse ignore qu'on peut s'abonner pour 10 PT par mois si elle le savait elle s'abonnerait De plus, dans son propre interet et dans celui de la population, la Compagnie des Eaux devrait faire certaines concessions. Quant aux enter rements, dont il est question dans le rapport de l'inspecteur sanitaire, Abani bey trouve qu'il y a ambiguité et qu'avec des agents de récution qui ne sont genéralement pas tres intelligents il serait nécessaire de préciser il fait remarquer ensuite que le person nel de désinfection étant recruté parmi des vagabonds sans foi ni loi, il y aurait lieu du moins de choisir avec soin les chefs d'équipe pour surveiller leurs faits et gee tes. Cette réforme est nécessaire pour en courager le public déclarer les cas C'est, en effet, pour éviter l'intervention d'un tel per sonnel que des ens ont été tenus secrets en 1902 M. Barbanza signale les écheobes de Chatby com me un véritable foyer de contagion en cas d'épi démie M. Rothacker demande . quoi vont aboutir tous ces beaux discours, il est d'avis qu'on vote quelque chose de précis. Sur sa proposition et après les explications de M l'Administrateur, les crédits demandes sont votés, ainsi que la feriaetore des puits con taminés.

En ce qui concerne l'examen des autres mesures prendre, l'affaire est renvoyée sur la proposition de M. l'Administrateur à la Déléga tion qui est toujours considérée en Egypte comme commission sanitaire en temps d'épide mie. Au sujet des échecbes M. l'Administra teur explique qu'il est impossible d'en chasser les babitants avant de leur avoir trouvé un autre lieu de résidence. Du reste, la Moni. cipalité apporte le plus grand soin à la désinfection de cette localité. D'autre part, M. l'Administrateur fers son possible avec M. Salvago pour obtenir des concessions de la

Sur le pouvelle que toutes les affaires de M Barns étaient arrangées par les ventes de ses propriétés, bormis cependant la Garden City, la Nile Land est remontée de 6 & 7 1/4, en bonne tendance

L Agricole progresse de 7 27 32 & 3, La Delta Light de 9 58 911 16. ln Bebera de 20 3/8 2012, len Privilégiées Biere d'Alexandre de 107 108, les Nungovich Hotels de 18 34 A 13 78, l'l'rbaine de 31883316, l'Hélouan de 18 25 32 et In 'assa di Sconto de 55 37 1 2

La Dira fechit, au contraire, de 13 13 13 13 16, Ia Delta Land de 1 7 321 3.16, Building Lands de 1716 1 3/8, l'Union Ponciere de 43 4 5/16, et l Levico de 16 A 9 32 La fondateur Zarifa tombe de 3 . 2 livres

Il n'y a pas d'autres changements signaler sur la cote la tendance générale parait terme Il ne saurait d'ailleure en étre autrement avec la succession de bonnes nouvelles provenant de noe places dirigeantes. Nous recevons l'ins tant une dépêche de Londres signalant une re prise sensible des valeurs, un retour de con fiance générale, la diminution du taux d'intérêt et une demande active des Consolides qui - inscrivent à 86 5/8
Toutefois, l'opinion locale est que notre marché ne pourra que difficilement suivre un mouvement de hausse, tant que le marche a terme ne sera pas rétabli

Il est question de former, sous les auspices de l'Agricole, une banque commerciale chargée d'avancer aux fellabs sur les produits de leur récolte. Nous dontons que ce projet puisse tre mis exécution dans les circonstances actuelles oh les établissements existants ont deja de la peine se procurer les sommes nécessaires dans ce but.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.
Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
